case_vignette: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his foster mother because of complaints from his teachers regarding poor performance at school for the past 8 months. He does not listen to their instructions, often talks during class, and rarely completes his school assignments. He does not sit in his seat in the classroom and often cuts in line at the cafeteria. His foster mother reports that he runs around a lot inside the house and refuses to help his sister with chores and errands. He frequently interrupts his foster mother's conversations with others and talks excessively. She has found him trying to climb on the roof on multiple occasions. He was placed in foster care because of neglect by his biological parents 3 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mental status examination shows a neutral affect.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having trouble listening to my teachers, I talk a lot during class, and I don't usually finish my homework.
How old are you?
I am 8 years old.
Have you had similar issues at school consistently?
Yes, my teachers have been complaining about my performance for the past 8 months.
Have you had any trouble with paying attention or being easily distracted in other settings, such as at home or with friends?
I run around a lot inside the house and I often interrupt conversations at home, plus I don't help out with chores and errands.
Have you been experiencing any other problems like impulsiveness or forgetfulness?
I talk excessively, cut in line at the cafeteria, and I've even tried to climb on the roof sometimes.
Do you have any family history of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or similar issues with attention and impulse control?
I don't know about my family history because I was placed in foster care due to neglect by my biological parents 3 years ago.
**Final Diagnosis:** Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
